Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Detection limit in marine nitrogen fixation measurements - Constraints of rates from the mesopelagic ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
The availability of nitrogen is required to support the growth and production of organisms living in the surface of our global ocean. This element can be scarce. To alleviate this scarcity, a special class of bacteria and archaea, called nitrogen fixers, can derive the nitrogen needed for growth from nitrogen gas. This project would carefully examine one specific method for measuring nitrogen fixation that has been used recently to suggest the occurrence of small amounts of nitrogen fixation in subsurface ocean waters. If these reports are verified, then a revision of our understanding of the marine nitrogen cycle may be needed. The Ocean Carbon and Biogeochemistry program will be used as a platform to develop community consensus for best practices in nitrogen fixation measurements and detection of diversity, activity, and abundances of the organisms responsible. In addition, a session will be organized in a future national/international conference to communicate with the broader scientific community while developing these best practices.

The goal of this study is to conduct a thorough examination of potential experimental and analytical errors inherent to the 15N2-tracer nitrogen fixation method, in tandem with comprehensive molecular measurements, in mesopelagic ocean waters. Samples will be collected and experimental work conducted on a cruise transect in the North Atlantic Ocean, followed by analytical work in the laboratory. The specific aims of this study are to (1) determine the minimum quantifiable rates of 15N2 fixation based on incubations of mesopelagic waters via characterization of sources of experimental and analytical error, and (2) seek evidence of presence and expression of nitrogen fixation genes via comprehensive molecular approaches on corresponding samples. The range of detectable rates and diazotroph activity from the measurements made in this study will be informative for the understanding of the importance of nitrogen fixation in the oceanic nitrogen budget.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nitrogen fixation in the ocean is a process by which certain species of phytoplankton utilize the abundant resource dinitrogen gas (N2) as a source of nutrition to fuel growth and reproduction. This process is a significant source of nitrogen to otherwise nitrogen-starved regions of the global ocean. This project was aimed at developing community consensus on how to best measure the rate of N2 fixation specifically in regions where rates are low. Subsequently we aimed to link these rates to gene-based estimates of the responsible organisms.  In 2017, we completed a research expedition aboard the R/V Endeavor in the North Atlantic. We made extensive and detailed measurements of N2 fixation rates and conducted a thorough error analysis. The outcomes of this research are the basis of a manuscript under consideration with the Journal of Geophysical Research (Palter et al. 2020). In this manuscript we report that direct measurements of N2 fixation and biogeochemical budgets in parallel indicate the Gulf Stream region of the Atlantic Ocean to be a biological hot spot for N2 fixation as a consequence of the relative transport of the nutrients phosphate and nitrate to surface waters in the region. In combination with our basic science goals, with ancillary support from the Ocean Carbon and Biogeochemistry (OCB) office, we also formed an international working group to develop "best practices" in nitrogen fixation measurements (https://www.us-ocb.org/n-fixation-working-group/). The objective of this working group was to use field and laboratory data to conduct a thorough assessment of the 15N2 tracer incubation method (accuracy, error analysis, detection limit, etc.) for measuring nitrogen fixation rates and accompanying molecular methods that identify responsible diazotrophs.  The path to community consensus included preparation and publication of "Chasing after Non-cyanobacterial Nitrogen Fixation in Marine Pelagic Environments" by Moisander et al. (2017, doi.org/10.3389/fmicb.2017.01736), a February 2018 town hall meeting at the annual Ocean Sciences meeting in Portland, Oregon, an in-person workshop in Dedham, MA in May 2018 that was attended by OCB working group members in order to formulate the scope of community recommendations, and preparation and publication of "A critical review of the 15N2 tracer method to measure diazotrophic production in pelagic ecosystems" by White et al. (2020, doi.org/10.1002/lom3.10353) which has been peer-reviewed and published in the journal Limnology and Oceanography Methods. In sum, the tangible outcomes of this project include field-based assessments of the activity and diversity of diazotrophs in the Gulf Stream (Palter et al. 2020) and community consensus on best practices for isotope-tracer based measurements of N2 fixation (White et al. 2020). We believe this project had benefitted all in the oceanographic community who study N2 fixation and poises us to more accurately understand this critical biological process in the global ocean.
